text.2: thou all mens friend visvamanas exaltest agni with thy song.

text.5: through whose discovering power the priest obtaineth wealth.
text.6: up springs the imperishable flame the flame of the refulgent one.
text.7: most bright with glowing jaws and glory in his train.
text.8: skilled in fair sacrifice extolled arise in godlike loveliness.
text.9: shining with lofty splendour with effulgent light.
text.10: called straight to our oblations come o agni through our eulogies.
text.11: as thou hast been our envoy bearing up our gifts.
text.12: i call your agni from of old invoking priest of living men.
text.13: him with this song i laud and magnify for you.
text.14: whom wondrous wise they animate with solemn rites and his fair form.
text.15: kind as a friend to men who keep the holy law.
text.16: him true to law who perfecteth the sacrifice lawloving ones.
text.17: ye with your song have gratified in the place of prayer.
text.18: may all our sacrifices go to him the truest aṅgiras.
text.19: who is among mankind the most illustrious priest.
text.20: imperishable agni thine are all these high enkindled lights.
text.21: like horses and like stallions showing forth their strength.
text.22: so give us lord of power and might riches combined with hero strength.
text.23: and guard us with our sons and grand sons in our frays.
text.24: soon as the eager lord of men is friendly unto mantis race.
text.25: agni averteth from us all the demon host.
text.26: o hero agni lord of men on hearing this new laud of mine.
text.27: burn down the rākṣasas enchanters with thy flame.
text.28: no mortal foe can eer prevail by arts of magic over him.
text.29: who serveth agni well with sacrificial gifts.
text.30: vyaśva the sage who sought the bull hath won thee finder of good things.
text.31: as such may we enkindle thee for ample wealth.
text.32: uśanā kāvya stablished thee o agni as invoking priest.
text.33: thee jātavedas sacrificing priest for man.
text.34: all deities of one accord appointed thee their messenger.
text.35: thou god through hearing hadst first claim to sacrifice.
text.36: him may the mortal hero make his own immortal messenger.
text.37: farspreading purifier him whose path is black.
text.38: with lifted ladles let us call him splendid with his brilliant flame.
text.39: mens ancient agni wasting not adorable.
text.40: the man who pays the worship due to him with sacrificial gifts.
text.41: obtains both plenteous nourishment and hero fame.
text.42: to jātavedas agni chief in sacrifices first of all.
text.43: with homage goes the ladle rich with sacred gifts.
text.44: even as vyatya did may we with these most high and liberal hymns.
text.45: pay worship unto agni of the splendid flame.

text.47: to agni of the home o Ṛṣi vyaśvas son.
text.48: as welcome guest of human kind as offspring of the forest kings.

text.50: for mens oblations brought to him who is the mighty lord of all.
